title: 110_s2761
content: The "Recapture Excess Profits and Invest in Roads (REPAIR) Act of 2008" includes a temporary windfall profits tax on crude oil under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This tax imposes rules and definitions for windfall profits. The "Recapture Excess Profits and Invest in Roads (REPAIR) Act of 2008" introduces an excise tax of 25 percent on windfall profits for applicable taxpayers in the United States, including integrated oil companies and other crude oil producers or refiners with over $1,000,000,000 in gross receipts. The term "windfall profit" is defined as the excess of adjusted taxable income over the average profit for the taxable year. Adjusted taxable income includes taxable income increased by certain deductions and reduced by interest and dividend income, as well as net operating losses. The adjusted taxable income for a foreign corporation is determined based on income effectively connected with a trade or business in the US. The reasonably inflated average profit for any taxable year is calculated as the average of adjusted taxable income for 2003-2007, plus 10 percent. "SEC. 5898. SPECIAL RULES AND DEFINITIONS." The Secretary will establish rules for tax withholding and deposit under section 5896. Taxpayers must maintain records and provide information as required. The Secretary will outline the filing process for the tax return under section 5896. The definition of crude oil includes condensates and natural gasoline. Businesses under common control are defined for this chapter. The Secretary will establish regulations for tax withholding and deposit under section 5896. Businesses under common control will be treated as 1 person. Regulations necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter will be prescribed. Chapter 56 discusses the temporary windfall profit on crude oil. The windfall profit tax on crude oil is deductible under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Proceeds from this tax are transferred to the Highway Trust Fund. The amendments apply to taxable years in 2008 and 2009. The amendments made in subsection (d) will take effect upon the enactment of this Act in 2008 and 2009.
